Ports of a Power Supply Unit

Storage is a very important component of the PC just like everything else in the PC. The storage component is a piece of hardware that has the capability to hold information within a certain time frame or forever.In other words, it is a place to store your data either temporarily or permanently.

The CPU (central processing unit) is often called the brain of the system because it handles instructions from both hardware and software. The CPU lives on on the motherboard in the CPU socket covered by a heat sink. The CPU at its most basic performs calculations from instructions itâ€™s sent from peripheral devices or inner hardware like the RAM. Today you will see many options for CPUs from different manufacturers with different line ups of product. Each CPU has its own amount of cores and architectures that differentiates it from other manufacturers or even from older generations of the same product. From experience, do not cheap out on this part of the computer because no expensive GPU or amount of RAM will stop the bottleneck that will occur because of an older low core CPU.

The motherboard acts as the foundation for all other computer parts to live on. It serves to route power to help coordinate how the components work together. It is not the same as the CPU since it does not make computations. The motherboard does more organization of the computation and results. It does not affect performance, but the sockets available will since an older CPU socket will only support older CPUs and more sockets for more RAM would increase the performance of the computer. The motherboard is also home to the BIOS(Basic Input/Output System) which allows you to view hardware information, change your boot drive, manage power settings, and overclock and underclock the CPU or RAM.

The memory or more commonly known as RAM (random access memory) is a short term memory location for the computer. Without RAM the computer would take much longer to open applications or do tasks. It is able to retrieve and store data the computer needs now or soon at high speeds. Unlike the actual storage of the computer, it only stores data when the computer is powered. The high speeds allow the CPU to do more computations without having to dig through a slower regular storage drive. RAM is usually bought in quantities of gigabytes(GB) in increments of 8 GBs in single stick or multiple all the way up to 128 GBs of RAM.

Storage is a very important component of the PC just like everything else in the PC. The storage component is a piece of hardware that has the capability to hold information within a certain time frame or forever. In other words, it is a place to store your data either temporarily or permanently.
Gives power to all the components in the PC.

Depending on the GPU you purchase and when you purchased it the ports on the GPU may differ a little, but not by too much. For example, if you were to purchase a GPU back in 2003 the ports that would be included with it would consist of the DVI port, a VGA port and a S-Video port. If you were to purchase the up and coming GPU in the market you would find yourself having many HDMI ports, some DisplayPorts and depending on the GPU manufacturer you could find yourself having a DVI or even a VGA port.

The main two companies producing CPUs are AMD and Intel. The core count can go from two all the way up to sixty-four for professional settings. Clock speed is another piece of information that is advertised a lot when shopping for CPUs. Clock speed is measured in megahertz(MHz) or gigahertz (GHz) and means how many instructions a CPU can handle per second. The speed of the computer will depend on multiple factors other than the clock speed like the other components.

The back panel of the motherboard holds many of the ports needed to attach peripherals to interact with the computer. Most newer boards contain a HDMI or Displayport for the monitor, usb ports for mouse and keyboard or any more accessories, and many I/O connectors.

Connection for the power cord to the computer, the fan that pulls out the heat from the internal of the PSU, a switch to change the voltage provided and a rocker switch to turn the power supply on and off.
